data.body: You can use the analyzer to help here.  Helps make dependencies more clear.

data.title: feat(change_detection): update change detection benchmark
data.body:
The current version of the benchmark is not very useful.

1. It creates 500 000 change detectors with one field read each. 
2. The baseline uses getters to run, which is slow (slower than the static change detection).

This PR rewrite the benchmark:
1. The baseline is static (and super fast).
2. We benchmark both the dynamic and static change detection.

data.title: Zone doesn't support WebSockets.
fix(NgRepeat): activate index
data.body: I'm not sure about the issue that was found by @rkirov , but the test can be passed now.

data.title: feat: change template micro-syntax to new syntax
data.body:
Old syntax:
- ng-repeat: #item in items;
- ng-repeat: #item; in: items;
- `<template let-ng-repeat=“item” [in]=items>`

New syntax:
- ng-repeat: var item in items;
- ng-repeat: var item; in items
- `<template ng-repeat var-item [in]=items>`


Notice that the var is now a standalone binding 
rather then an argument to ng-repeat. This will 
make the var bindings consistent with the rest of 
the system.

data.body:
1) `pub global activate dart_style`
2) `pub global run dart_style:format -w [path_to_dart_code]`

If you've activated dart_style and added the right path to your environment, you can run `dart_formatter` directly.

But if you were scripting this in gulp, `pub global run dart_style:format` is the way to go

data.title: Update async dart webdriver
data.body:
The preferred way of writing e2e tests for Dart right now is using the [dart-sync-webdriver](https://github.com/google/dart-sync-webdriver). However, the sync version requires a dart native extension, which is hard to build (no automated build scripts, not on `dartlang.org`, ...). As dart is getting [`async`/`await`](https://www.dartlang.org/articles/await-async/) soon, the async version will be the preferred way of writing e2e tests in Dart.

Right now, the [async webdriver for dart](https://github.com/google/dart-sync-webdriver) is about a year old and needs to be updated.

data.title: [Question] Horizontal visibility for directive injection
data.body:
In the documentation, the visibility constraints specified are all vertical (@ancestor, @parent, @child and @descendant). What about horizontal ones please? Have they been considered ? I'm raising this question because, for me, it would quite quite natural and elegant to write something like this in a template: ```
``` or ```
hello2 helloElse
``` To implement such a `ng-else` directive, a visibility constraint like @previous or @before is needed. More generally, it seems a good idea to be able to link sibling directives without having to create an extra parent directive. What do you think please ? For information, I did quick and dirty implementation of `ng-else` to find out how it could be done: https://github.com/mlaval/angular/commit/df56d40ef1589cb8f14c97e3f61ec3ca956a08f1 Before moving forward and implementing that in a cleaner way, I wanted to discuss it with you.

data.title: benchpress: rewrite chromedriver integration to use tracing data
data.body:
Right now we are using the old timeline data. However, the Timeline in DevTools already uses tracing data.

See https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/logging/performance-log

Use category `disabled-by-default-devtools.timeline`

Open problem: How to get the process id of a page in chromedriver, as the performance log contains all tabs

data.title: Protractor wait integration
data.body:
First step:

Inject a JS script after calling the main method in JS / including the main script in Dart that allows protractor to call this in the browser (see https://github.com/angular/protractor/blob/master/lib/clientsidescripts.js#L37)
```
angular.getTestability(el).whenStable(callback);
```

data.title: Better component test coverage
data.body:
Angular apps are made of Dart/JS as well as template code. Both Dart and JS have good code coverage tools. However high coverage of Dart/JS does not translate to a well tested Angular app. Your bindings could be broken. Templates could have errors.

Angular 2 should provide a way for a test to measure the completeness of a component test by watching the templates and bindings exercised in a test. These metrics could then be aggregated into a report. Teams would then set goals based on these metrics, just like they do for code coverage.

data.body:
- [ ] Have prod / dev mode where prod mode strips out all bindings from template to make cloning faster
- [ ] Do `template.content.firstChild.cloneNode()` instead of `template.cloneNode().content.firstChild`.
- [ ] Use `firstChild`, `nextChild` for small templates instead of `getElementByClassName`
- [ ] Use anchor as last element instead of first element to make `insertBefore` more efficient. Have Starting anchor in dev mode only.

data.title: Implement DOM write and DOM read queues

milestone.title: M3: Solidify Foundation
milestone.description:
ChangeDetection
- Support chained expressions
- Parse from AST

Parser:
- Generate AST fro all expressions

data.body:
Every `View` should have a queue of dom write operations and and a queue of dom read operations.  

1. All dom operations should be ran in the queues. 
2. Write operations must run bottom up (child view, then parent view).
3. We need to flush the queues on digest.
